## Background
### <span style="color:#FFD54A; font-size:1.25em; font-weight:700;">Ongoing Housing Stress</span>

-   Housing is a major pathway through which health disparities emerge and are sustained over time [@Swope2019-gm]

-   771,480 people experienced homelessness in the U.S. [@De_Sousa2024-br]

<br>

### Cognitive Domains of Interest

:::  columns
::: {.column width="50%"}
<span style="color:#FFD54A; font-size:1.25em; font-weight:700;">Episodic Memory</span>

-   Verbal episodic memory shows high predictive accuracy (\>0.7)
-   High sensitivity and specificity (â‰¥80%) for AD identification [@Weissberger2017-vb]
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
<span style="color:#FFD54A; font-size:1.25em; font-weight:700;">Working Memory</span>

-   Working memory deficits are a recognized feature of AD
-   Related to frontal lobe dysfunction [@Stopford2012-bs]
:::
::: 



## Why Does This Issue Matter?

### Housing Instability Implications

-   Foreclosure may endanger older adults' memory [@Kim2024-se]

-   Housing distress associated with increased risk of cognitive impairment (RR = 1.20) [@Wilkinson2026-wu]

<br>

### Cognitive Function Implications
-   Mid-life and late-life cognitive functions are associated with AD risks [@Dhana2025-pq]

-   MCI patients have 10-fold higher risk of progressing to dementia [@Belleville2017-sr]

<br>

::: {.callout-warning .big-callout }
### What Don't We Know?

-   Causal effect of housing stress on cognitive decline is not well established

-   Few studies have investigated detailed cognitive assessments:
:::


## Research Question

<br>

This research question is examining: 

<br>

<span style="color:#FFD54A; font-size:1.25em; font-weight:700;">The average causal effect of ongoing housing stress on multiple cognitive domains(**Episodic Memory** and **Working Memory**) among adults aged 50 and older in the United States</span>
